node.text:
Still I rise... On June 19, 1865, US Brigadier General Gordon Granger and his troops landed at Galveston, Texas, confirming the news that the Civil War had ended and that enslaved African Americans were now free. #Juneteenth commemorates this important milestone. Although the ratification of the 13th Amendment in December 1865 ultimately abolished slavery, the struggle for equality continues today. Through the lens of our nation’s iconic places, the National Park Service has a responsibility to advance understanding of our nation’s unique and complex history. We invite you to watch “Twenty & Odd,” which builds on the innumerable contributions of African Americans to the foundation of the nation and explores the trauma, resilience, and beauty of the African American experience.

#FindYourPark #NationalParkService

node.text:
Set against 400 years of suffering, healing, and strength, with a backdrop of our nation’s most storied lands, the innumerable contributions of African Americans to the foundation of the United States are recognized in this short film.

#TwentyandOdd #NationalParkService #AfricanAmericanHistory #FindYourPark #StillIRise

node.title: Twenty & Odd: 400 Years of African American Experience

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 23, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
One bison, two bison, three bison… 🦬⁣
⁣
This week, a team of National Park Service interns with @mosaicsinscience_nps and @lhip_interns headed to Wind Cave National Park to participate in a bison survey and tour the cave as part of #LatinoConservationWeek. During the trip, they learned about the park’s extensive prairie landscape and its wildlife (especially bison and prairie dogs). They also learned about the cave’s discovery, exploration, and its significance as a spiritual place to many.⁣
⁣
The group also helped the park’s wildlife biologist do a count of bison in the park. A regular count helps Wind Cave keep track of how fast the bison population is growing and can monitor the herd to make sure the animals, and their habitat, are protected and conserved for future generations. By the end of the count, between 110 to 130 bison, including 12 calves, were observed. The count was done from a safe distance. Binoculars up! ⁣
⁣
Of the experience, LHIP intern Nicole Segnini said, “This was not only a great educational opportunity for us, but it was also a great way to connect with people who share the same love for nature and conservation and to experience the outdoors like some of us had never done before. Some of us had never even seen a bison, others had never gone camping! This trip also encouraged me to learn more about conservation efforts and wildlife at our parks, and to head outside to discover unfamiliar and unique places and enjoy their beauty and history.” ⁣
⁣
Images: Led by park biologist, a group surveys the landscape and helps count bison at South Dakota’s @windcavenps.⁣
⁣
#LCW2021 #nationalparkservice #southdakota #windcavenationalpark #bison ⁣

node.text:
Hey @tsa, we saw your recent post. What kind of trees are those? Hopefully, a last minute gate change didn’t lead to an awkward dismount…⁣
⁣
If airport lounging is not your thing, some good places to “sway and chill” are @glaciernps, @craterlakenps, and @hawaiivolcanoesnps. Although hammocks are allowed in most national parks, keep in mind that each park has specific guidelines for hammock use. That may include hammocks only being allowed in developed campgrounds or requiring you to use a stand. (Support trees by supporting yourself!) We always recommend checking a park’s website, or asking a park ranger, before attempting the “Is anyone watching, this is not going to be graceful!” maneuver when getting into a hammock. If attaching to trees, pick a sturdy pair, and think about using padding between the hammock straps and the trees to prevent any damage. Otherwise, enjoy the breeze and good luck getting out…oh, ugh, careful…don’t fight it. This is where you live now. ⁣
⁣
Image: While resting in a hammock, a visitor enjoys the mountain views from Bowman Lake in @glaciernps. Photo by Jacob W. Frank ⁣
⁣
#hammocklife #nationalhammockday #nationalparkservice #tsa #recreateresponsibly #tsanpscollab

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Yellowstone National Park. May be an image of animal and nature.

node.text:
Can I pet that dog?⁣
⁣
No. Bison calves tend to be born from late March through May and are orange-red in color, earning them the nickname "red dogs." After a few months, their hair starts to change to dark brown and their characteristic shoulder hump and horns begin to grow. Like all wild animals, bison can be dangerous and unpredictable. They are capable of charging and bringing pain who approach too closely. An indicator that a bison may be about to charge is the position of its tail: if it's standing straight up, it's a serious watch-out situation. As with all wildlife, it's important to observe them from a distance.⁣ And don’t pet that dog.
⁣
Image: An adult bison surrounded by three calves “red dogs” standing in the grass at @yellowstonenps. NPS⁣
⁣
#bison #yellowstone #nature #reddog #canipetthatdog

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. May be a closeup.

node.text:
I don't alway wear leopard print, but when i do, i'm like a tiger.⁣
⁣
It's #NationalMothWeek! The word "moth" may conjure up images of drab and furry insects sticking to your screen door on a summer night, but moths serve our ecosystem in many ways, including pollination and providing food for many other creatures. The giant leopard moth (Hypercompe scribonia), sometimes referred to as Eyed Tiger Moth, is a beautiful large white moth that is easy to identify. (Hint: Its the spots.) Its wings have a pattern of black and shiny black/blue dots (some solid and some hollow) sprinkled across them. Maybe it should be the Dalmatian moth? Spot on! It has a wingspan of three inches, and when its wings are spread, you can see its colorful abdomen: The top side is iridescent blue with orange markings, while the underside is white with solid black dots. One might think that’s a lot of color and pattern happening, but it works! ⁣
⁣
P.S. When handled or threatened, the Giant leopard moth may release drops of foul-tasting yellow fluid from its thorax to ward off predators. That’s a sure fire way to assure some space. ⁣
⁣
What do you know about moths? ⁣
⁣
Image: Giant leopard moth resting against a wall at @greatsmokynps. NPS/A. Bate⁣
⁣
#moth #leopardmoth #greatsmokymountains #tennessee #mothsofinstagram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 20, 2021. May be an image of mountain, nature and sky.

node.text:
Fifty-two years ago, on July 20, 1969, the Lu­nar Mod­ule Eagle landed on the moon. For the first time, hu­mans set foot on a sur­face be­yond the Earth. Though the moon is a giant leap (238,900 miles) from Earth, it only takes a few small steps to get a spectacular view of it from one of your national parks. Your parks are home to stellar views of night skies. They have also been places for innovative scientific research and planning on the ground. Many parks, like @cratersofthemoon_nps in Idaho and @hawaiivolcanoesnps, were used for training future astronauts. Today, the National Park Service and @nasa continue to collaborate on research, data collection, and outreach. ⁣
⁣
Image 1: Full moon over the landscape of Hawaii Volcanoes. NPS/Janice Wei⁣
⁣
Image 2: In January 1965, Astronauts explored Hawai’i Volcanoes including: Buzz Aldrin (Apollo 11), William Anders, Neil Armstrong (Apollo 11), Charles Basset, Alan Bean (Apollo 12), Roger Chaffee, Michael Collins (Apollo 11), Charles Conrad (Apollo 12), Walt Cunningham, Don Eisele (Apollo 7), Dick Gordon (Apollo 12), Rusty Schweikart, Dave Scott, Elliot See, and C.C. Williams, Jr. ⁣
⁣
Image 3: Trail winds through rocky terrain at Craters of the Moon. Since much of the moon's surface is covered by volcanic materials, it was important that Apollo 14 astronauts Alan Shepard, Edgar Mitchell, Joe Engle, and Eugene Cernan knew something about the lava they would encounter. Visiting Craters of the Moon National Monument allowed the astronauts to become educated observers who could describe the surface features they were exploring to geologists back on Earth. NPS/Jacob W. Frank⁣
⁣
#moonlanding #astronaut #nasa #nationalparkservice #fullmoon #nightskies #nasa

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 20, 2021. May be an image of mountain, nature and sky.
Photo by National Park Service on July 20, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.
Photo by National Park Service on July 20, 2021. May be an image of nature.
Photo by National Park Service in Katmai National Park & Preserve. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
They told me I could be anything...so I became a frog.⁣
⁣
This bear is quite ribbeting. 🐸 Bears, like people, are individuals and they develop different habits and preferences. Maybe you sit on a rock all day? Good for you. Bear 94, a medium-large adult female who resides at @katmainpp, is known for frequently sitting on rocks, especially this one. (We all need hobbies.) Perhaps a comfy resting spot? Is it a familiar perch to enjoy the peaceful sounds of the river? Maybe it’s a place to reflect on the metaphysical concepts of existence, purpose, and lunch? We may never know the real reason, but we do know it’s important that all who visit Katmai respect bears and visit the park with the knowledge to stay safe in the great outdoors.⁣
⁣
Image: Frog pose? Check. A bear rocks sitting on a rock in the middle of river. NPS Photo/L. Law⁣
⁣
#mood #bear #katmainationalpark #nationalparkservice #frogger #bearycute

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'NATIONAL PARK SERVICE ල LATINO'.

node.text:
Join us for #LatinoConservationWeek!  This annual celebration seeks to engage the Latino community (and everyone) in National Park Service recreational activities and stewardship that benefit local communities and parks. How can you get involved? ⁣
⁣
🗺 Explore stories of Latino heritage found in national parks and communities through preservation programs.⁣
⁣
🛶 Check out various internship and volunteer opportunities for youth of all ages to get hands-on experience in conservation.⁣
⁣
🔭 Be active in conservation of public lands and your community through volunteer projects and citizen science.⁣
⁣
🌲 Find ideas for enjoying nature through endless recreational opportunities in national parks and your own neighborhood.⁣
⁣
Learn more at nps.gov⁣
⁣
Image: Graphic features a black background with a colorful ranger hat in the center made up of various decorative and park related symbols and including a bison, canoe, sun, eagle, etc. The top heading text reads "National Parks Service” and a heading under the ranger hat reads “Latino Conservation Week."⁣
⁣
#LCW2021 #EncuentraTuParque #NationalParkService #conservation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 18, 2021. May be an image of hat.

node.text:
Have a question? Ask a ranger. When you arrive at a park, locate the Visitor Center or Ranger Station and ask a ranger about:⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⚠️ Closures or Postings - Are there any trails, campsites, or other areas closed or posted due to hazardous conditions that may change your planned itinerary?⁣⁣
⁣⁣
🐊 Hazards - Are the alligators real? Is there any fire or animal activity, high water from recent rain events, rock fall, or icy trails and routes? Are you visiting a historic structure with uneven steps, unleveled paths, or no barriers to protect you from falls?⁣⁣
⁣⁣
☔️ Weather Changes - Is there rain, wind, snow, or extreme temperatures (high or low) forecasted for the duration of your trip?⁣⁣
⁣⁣
🚽 Restrooms - We’ll point you in the right direction. Over there, around the bend, just out back. Insider tip: Always check supplies before you commit. ⁣
⁣
Image: Upclose view of a ranger hat with woods in the background.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
#PlanLikeAParkRanger #nationalparkservice #parkranger #hat #travelgram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 18, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and brick wall.

node.text:
Picturesque Fort Washington sits on high ground overlooking the Potomac River and offers a grand view of Washington, D.C. and the Virginia shoreline. Built to defend the river approach to Washington, DC, Maryland’s Fort Washington has stood as silent sentry for over 200 years. As technologies advanced so did Fort Washington, from the brick and stone of the 19th century to the concrete and steel of the 20th century. Today, the expansive grounds of the present Fort Washington Park, with its extensive hiking/bicycle paths and river view, are a scenic venue for picnicking, fishing, and outdoor recreation. ⁣
⁣
Image 1: Looking through the arched sally port (entrance) of Fort Washington.⁣
⁣
Image 2: View of interior buildings of fort from upper ramparts with empty cannon tracks.⁣
⁣
Image: View of a yellow brick house, built in 1921 for the fort's commander, atop a grassy hill.⁣
⁣
#maryland #FortWashington #washingtondc #fortification #forts #historicpreservation @civilwardefensesofwashington

node.text:
Every time you think you have all your ducks in a row, one of the little fluffs starts to wander off! 🦆🦆🦆⁣
⁣
Want to check out some ducks in real life? Head over to Constitution Gardens in Washington D.C. One of the smaller outdoor units of the National Park System, the centerpiece of Constitution Gardens is a small lake lined with trees. This oasis in the cityscape attracts a variety of urban wildlife, including some of the more than 200 species of birds that are spotted in the area throughout the year.⁣
⁣
Image: Four Young Mallard ducklings swimming in a row with one facing the opposite direction. Photo/Jane Gamble⁣
⁣
#DucksInARow #washingtondc #nationalparkservice #ducksofinstagram  #constitutiongardens

node.text:
The beaver content you didn’t know you needed. ⁣
⁣
The beaver (Castor canadensis) North America’s largest rodent. Adult beavers typically weigh 45 to 60 pounds, but have been known to grow to 100 pounds. Beaver fur consists of short fine hairs for warmth and longer hairs for waterproofing. They eagerly groom their fur daily to keep it waterproof, and frequently groom each other’s fur. They have castor glands on the under side of their abdomen from which they can excrete an oily substance (castor) that they use in the grooming process, and to mark their territory. ⁣
⁣
Video: Keep it clean, folks. A beaver sits near the river at Utah’s @zionnps and grooms its fur. NPS/Avery Sloss⁣
⁣
#ZionNationalPark #utah #wildlife #naturelover

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Big Bend National Park. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
It’s a cross between a spider and a scorpion that shoots acetic “vinegar” from a “whip.” That’s it folks. Have a good one.⁣
⁣
Still with us? This is the bug content you’ve been looking for. The vinegaroon, or whip scorpion, is an arachnid of the order Thelyphonida, a small group of arachnids comprised of only 100 species. The name "whip scorpion" refers to their resemblance to true scorpions and possession of a whiplike tail, and "vinegaroon" refers to their ability when attacked to discharge an offensive, vinegar-smelling liquid, which contains acetic acid. Good times.⁣
⁣
At @bigbendnps, summer rains bring vinegaroons out of their burrows in search of food and love. Vinegaroons are about 3 inches long and relatively benign unless you happen to annoy them. (True for most of us.) They can pinch with their heavy mouthparts (pedipalps) and shoot a well-aimed spray of 85% acetic acid (vinegar) from the base of their "whip" to protect themselves. They hunt millipedes, scorpions, crickets, cockroaches, and other invertebrates by sensing vibrations with their long, thin front legs. ⁣
⁣
Most commonly seen in the desert, this vinegaroon was taking a stroll around the Chisos Basin campground. If you're lucky enough to see this cool creature, look closely. If it's a female, she may be carrying her hatchlings on her back. You’re welcome. ⁣
⁣
Image: Large black vinegaroon showing thin "whip" tail; long, thin front legs; and heavy mouthparts that serve as pincers. NPS/CA Hoyt⁣
⁣
#Vinegaroon #Whipscorpion #ChihuahuanDesert #DesertCreatures #BigBend #FindYourPark #texas
